functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.

msg.content: Which heads of state of the founding countries of the European Union are older than 80 years old?
Which heads of state of the founding countries of the European Union are older than 80 years old?

| 1969 |
| Prime Minister under Charles de Gaulle (1962–1968). Elected President in the 1969 election against the centrist Alain Poher. Favoured European integration. Supported economic modernisation and industrialisation. Faced the 1973 oil crisis. †Died in office of Waldenström's macroglobulinemia, two years before the end of his mandate. |
| —

 | Democratic Centre (CD)
 | [46] |
| Interim President again, as President of the Senate. Did not stand against Valéry Giscard d'Estaing in the 1974 election. |

<title>List of heads of state of Germany</title>
<fragment>
| Portrait
 | Bundespräsident | Took office | Left office | Time in office | Party | Election
 |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| ![Theodor Heuss](image)
 | Heuss, Theodor**Theodor Heuss**(1884–1963) | 13 September 1949 | 12 September 1959 | 9 years, 364 days |  | FDP | 19491954 |
| ![Heinrich Lübke](image)
 | Lübke, Heinrich**Heinrich Lübke**(1894–1972) | 13 September 1959 | 30 June 1969(*resigned*) | 9 years, 290 days |  | CDU | 19591964 |
| ![Gustav Heinemann](image)
 | Heinemann, Gustav**Gustav Heinemann**(1899–1976) | 1 July 1969 | 30 June 1974 | 4 years, 364 days |  | SPD | 1969 |
| ![Walter Scheel](image)
 | Scheel, Walter**Walter Scheel**(1919–2016) | 1 July 1974 | 30 June 1979 | 4 years, 364 days |  | FDP | 1974 |
| ![Karl Carstens](image)
 | Carstens, Karl**Karl Carstens**(1914–1992) | 1 July 1979 | 30 June 1984 | 4 years, 365 days |  | CDU | 1979 |
| ![Richard von Weizsäcker](image)

</fragment>
<fragment>
 | Honecker, Erich**Erich Honecker**(1912–1994) | 29 October 1976 | 18 October 1989(*resigned*) | 12 years, 354 days |  | SED |
| ![Egon Krenz](image)
 | Krenz, Egon**Egon Krenz**(born 1937) | 18 October 1989 | 6 December 1989(*resigned*) | 49 days |  | SED |
| ![Manfred Gerlach](image)
 | Gerlach, Manfred**Manfred Gerlach**(1928–2011) | 6 December 1989 | 5 April 1990(*office abolished*) | 120 days |  | LDPD |
| President of the People's Chamber*Präsident der Volkskammer* |
| ![Sabine Bergmann-Pohl](image)
 | Bergmann-Pohl, Sabine**Sabine Bergmann-Pohl**(born 1946) | 5 April 1990 | 2 October 1990(*East Germany joined Federal Republic*) | 180 days |  | CDU |


## Styles of the Heads of State[edit]


Unified state (1871 to 1945)


</fragment>

| * v
* t
* e

| --- |
| German Reich (1871–1945) | ***Emperors***: Wilhelm I • Frederick III • Wilhelm II
***Presidents***: Friedrich Ebert • Paul von Hindenburg • Adolf Hitler (*Führer and Reichskanzler*) • Karl Dönitz
 |
| Federal Republic of Germany (since 1949) | * Theodor Heuss
* Heinrich Lübke
* Gustav Heinemann
* Walter Scheel
* Karl Carstens
* Richard von Weizsäcker
* Roman Herzog
* Johannes Rau
* Horst Köhler
* Christian Wulff
* Joachim Gauck
* Frank-Walter Steinmeier
 |
| East Germany (1949–1990) | * Wilhelm Pieck
* Walter Ulbricht
* Willi Stoph
* Erich Honecker
* Egon Krenz
* Manfred Gerlach
* Sabine Bergmann-Pohl

| *Italics* indicates acting holder

</document>

## Presidents[edit]


Under the Constitution, the first constitution of the Republic of Italy, the President replaced the monarch as ceremonial head of state. The President was elected by Parliament and Regional governments for a seven-year term. In the event of a vacancy the President of the Senate served as Acting President.




</fragment>
<fragment>
| **—** | ![](image) | **Nicola Mancino**(1931–) | **—** | 15 May1999
 | 18 May1999
 | —
 |
| As President of the Senate he acted as President until after the 1999 presidential election |
| **10** | ![](image) | **Carlo Azeglio Ciampi**(1920–2016) | **1** | 18 May1999
 | 15 May2006
 | 1999 — 71.41%707
 |
| Resigned |
| **11** | ![](image) | **Giorgio Napolitano**(1925–2023) | **1** | 15 May2006
 | 20 April2013
 | 2006 — 54.85%543
 |
| **2** | 20 April2013
 | 14 January2015
 | 2013 — 74.10%738
 |
| Resigned |
| **—** | ![](image) | **Pietro Grasso**(1945–) | **—** | 14 January2015
 | 3 February2015
 | —
 |
| As President of the Senate he acted as President until after the 2015 presidential election |
| **12** | ![](image) | **Sergio Mattarella**(1941–) | **1** | 3 February2015
 | Incumbent
 | 2015 — 65.91%665
 |


## Styles[edit]




</fragment>
</document>

msg.name: search

msg.content:
The search results provided information on the heads of state for France, Germany, and Italy. However, there were no specific lists found for Belgium, Luxembourg, and the Netherlands. Based on the available information, here are the heads of state of the founding countries of the European Union who are older than 80 years old:

### France
1. **Valéry Giscard d'Estaing** (1926–2020) - Former President of France.
2. **Jacques Chirac** (1932–2019) - Former President of France.

### Germany
1. **Walter Scheel** (1919–2016) - Former President of Germany.
2. **Richard von Weizsäcker** (1920–2015) - Former President of Germany.
3. **Roman Herzog** (1934–2017) - Former President of Germany.
4. **Johannes Rau** (1931–2006) - Former President of Germany.
5. **Horst Köhler** (1943–) - Former President of Germany.
6. **Joachim Gauck** (1940–) - Former President of Germany.

### Italy
1. **Giorgio Napolitano** (1925–2023) - Former President of Italy.
2. **Carlo Azeglio Ciampi** (1920–2016) - Former President of Italy.

For Belgium, Luxembourg, and the Netherlands, additional searches or specific queries might be needed to find the relevant information.

The search results provided information on the heads of state for France, Germany, and Italy. However, there were no specific lists found for Belgium, Luxembourg, and the Netherlands. Based on the available information, here are the heads of state of the founding countries of the European Union who are older than 80 years old:

### France
1. **Valéry Giscard d'Estaing** (1926–2020) - Former President of France.
2. **Jacques Chirac** (1932–2019) - Former President of France.

### Germany
1. **Walter Scheel** (1919–2016) - Former President of Germany.
2. **Richard von Weizsäcker** (1920–2015) - Former President of Germany.
3. **Roman Herzog** (1934–2017) - Former President of Germany.
4. **Johannes Rau** (1931–2006) - Former President of Germany.
5. **Horst Köhler** (1943–) - Former President of Germany.
6. **Joachim Gauck** (1940–) - Former President of Germany.

### Italy
1. **Giorgio Napolitano** (1925–2023) - Former President of Italy.
2. **Carlo Azeglio Ciampi** (1920–2016) - Former President of Italy.

For Belgium, Luxembourg, and the Netherlands, additional searches or specific queries might be needed to find the relevant information.
